Problem:
Consider a control system where the output \\( z(t) \\) is governed by the integral transformation \\( z(t) = \\int_0^t e^{At}(t-s)p(s)ds \\), and where \\( A \\) is a constant matrix and \\( p(t) \\) is the input signal. The integral kernel \\( e^{At} \\) represents the system's response to the input, transitioning over time.

If at time \\( t_1 < T \\), an intervention modifies \\( A \\) to a new matrix \\( B \\), thereby changing the system's dynamics, will the final output \\( z(T) \\) still only rely on the original matrix \\( A \\)?
Explanation: The intervention which modifies the matrix from \\( A \\) to \\( B \\) at time \\( t_1 \\) introduces a new dynamic to the system. This modification affects how the input signal \\( p(t) \\) is integrated from \\( t_1 \\) to T, thus the output \\( z(T) \\) now depends on both \\( A \\) and \\( B \\).
